p: Questions had already been raised about H5N1 as the source of the next influenza pandemic [ 134, 135], so its spread out of Asia was of continued concern. Reinforcing these fears, by early 2009 H5N1 was endemic through southeastern Asia, had spread through Eurasia and Africa, and was established in domestic bird populations. It had also caused several hundred human deaths with estimated case-fatality ratios of around 30â€“80% depending on the country [ 125] (although the real case-fatality ratio could be different due to case definitions, survey methods and reporting [ 136]). There was also evidence for limited person to person spread [ 137, 138].
